Patch Set 5:

This written in documentation:
Write notifiers should normally be disabled immediately after the activated() signal has been emitted.

Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 5:

> Это нужно делать, потому что сразу получаете спам сигналов о разрешении на запись.

Translate: This needs to be done because you immediately receive spam signals about write permission.

That behavior is correct, when you enable the write notifier, then it always will continue emit the activated() signals. It is ok.

A main idea is do not disable the notifier when a queue is not empty. You can disable it only when a queue becomes empty, because now nothing to write. 

And, I don't understand, why we disable it before writing and enable it after writing... It has not sense, IMHO.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

> Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Isn't right to test before vote?
I'd rather vote for this patch (if I could) because it looks right, and error may be not in socketcan plugin, but imho anyway it shouldn't be accepted before successful testing pass.
Uploaded patch set 6.
Patch Set 6: Sanity-Review+1

Patch Set 6:

PS6 is an optimized version. While PS5 slowed down writing quite a bit, this one writes as much as possible at once, and then falls back to the notifier.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

wait, PS6 is not good - it can loose frames. beside that, it does not go to buffer overrun. so it will need slightly adjustment.

Patch Set 6:

Ok, I have a problem here... I'd need to know if the socket is ready for writing before dequeuing a frame... because if I cannot write I need to keep the frame in the outgoing frames list.

Any ideas?

Patch Set 6:

Hi Evgeny,

if you want to improve this commit, please feel free to do so!

There is a UPDATE CHANGE link right hand side above the changed files, it contains the instructions how to do so.

It looks like your proposal would work, so if you can provide an updated patch I'd be happy to test it.

I'll most likely not have time to continue working here before the weekend.

Thanks and regards,
André

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Hi Evgeny,
> 
> if you want to improve this commit, please feel free to do so!
> 
> There is a UPDATE CHANGE link right hand side above the changed files, it contains the instructions how to do so.
> 
> It looks like your proposal would work, so if you can provide an updated patch I'd be happy to test it.
> 
> I'll most likely not have time to continue working here before the weekend.
> 
> Thanks and regards,
> André

Could I write and add that method to this commit?

Patch Set 7:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> > Do you think that proposed patch may stuck after ENOBUFS occurrence in infinite loop? 
> 
> Yes, it is possible in theory.. Besides, it is blocking approach in any case... E.g. we always check in a loop when the enobufs disappeared. It is blockning... it's bad idea (pseodocode):
> 
>  while (...) {
>      ret = write(...);
>      if (ret == enobufs)
>          continue; 
>  }
> 
> It is bad idea, because CPU is faster than a CAN-bus speed... in this case it can spent a lot of while() cycles until 'enobuf' disappeared.

write is nonblocking be default - and that is the whole reason for this patch.

You can make write blocking, but that's not what I want.

So while you are right, that with the loop there might be some cycles when writing, I don't think it is a problem. On the other hand, writing to the socket and then waiting for the notifier to trigger again makes writing _much_ slower, therefore I prefer the loop.

According to  https://rtime.felk.cvut.cz/can/socketcan-qdisc-final.pdf :

EAGAIN error instead of ENOBUFS."

Hi everybody.
I've writen two tests:
Test#1. Based on socketcan plugin from this patch (https://github.com/eugesh/socketcan-canbus-plugin/blob/read_longUniCAN_verify/tests/main.cpp);
Test#2. Changes cangen.c from can-utils to send set of CAN frames without a gap in loop: https://github.com/eugesh/can-utils/tree/cangen_longCAN
branch cangen_longCAN
I used vcan0 recommended by Andre:
```
sudo modprobe vcan echo=1
sudo ip link add dev vcan0 type vcan
sudo ip link set vcan0 up txqueuelen 100
sudo ip link set vcan0 up mtu 72
sudo tc qdisc add dev vcan0 root tbf rate 1mbit burst 24b limit 10000
```
What ifconfig says me (all right):
```
vcan0     Link encap:UNSPEC  HWaddr 00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00-00  
          UP RUNNING NOARP  MTU:72  Metric:1
          RX packets:6500000 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:6500000 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:100 
          RX bytes:52000000 (52.0 MB)  TX bytes:52000000 (52.0 MB)
```
Results:
Test#1: Wireshark received all CAN frames but 2 frames were sent (or received) in inappropriate order (0.03% or 2 of 6`500`000).
Test#2: Wireshark received not all CAN frames: 437 CAN frames were lost from 6`500`000 .
According to ifconfig counters the both tests writes all frames.
My actual conclusion only is that Wireshark receives frames a bit slower than the above tests write them. And Test#2 writes them faster than Test#1.

Also I used 
```
$ candump vcan0 > some_file.txt
```
And it looses frames while reading any of the above tests.

Thanks.

> When I perform my tests I see that system counters show me 100% sent and received CAN frames, but candump or Whireshark not. Reader based on socketcan plugin from QtSerialBus receives 100% frames too. But sometimes I see some frames received not in correct order.

If a second CAN node does not receive all messages we sent out, then the system is fundamentally broken. Tx/Rx counters are useless in that regards, the message needs to appear at the other node.

I'm pretty sure an earlier patch set did work correctly, as I verified that. I don't know which patch set that was, though.

Probably the first step would be to have the send/receive test framework, for easy checking that a change does not break existing function.

Thanks for your effort!

Best regards

Today I've written QTest which just calls writeFrame in a loop many times and finishes after that. The effect was nul written frames. When I added enterLoop at the end I saw all frames written. (Except the case when I caught  "QFATAL :  Test function timed out" when I called enterLoop with too huge value). 
When I use QApplication instead of QTest I see normal result. That heppens because writeFrame just enqueues frames and doesn't wait for writting them. If application finishes just after writeFrame call - no frames would be written.

Patch Set 16:

Hi Evgeny,

> Could you give me please link to app which you use for testing?

That is https://codereview.qt-project.org/c/qt/qtserialbus/+/292694/2

> Today I've written QTest which just calls writeFrame in a loop many times and finishes after that. The effect was nul written frames.

That is probably because the Qt event loop is not running here, so the socket notifers and the delayed writing will not work.

> When I added enterLoop at the end I saw all frames written. (Except the case when I caught  "QFATAL :  Test function timed out" when I called enterLoop with too huge value). 

Ok, that sounds as expected.

> When I use QApplication instead of QTest I see normal result. That heppens because writeFrame just enqueues frames and doesn't wait for writting them. If application finishes just after writeFrame call - no frames would be written.

But even that sounds as expected. It would only work if the frames are already in the Operating Systems / Kernel buffer.

Which might be another solution. There is a Kernel buffer, it just has limited size. Can we increase this buffer from our SocketCAN plugin? Then probably we could avoid keeping our own buffer...

> > I'm pretty sure an earlier patch set did work correctly, as I verified that. I don't know which patch > set that was, though.
> 
> Which patch set did you use?

As said, I don't know which was the last working one. The first patches were really slow on writing, but I think they did not loose frames.

I added is_error_state flag and enter the EventLoop checking that flag. And app exits without hanging.
Any suggestion or I add it to patch?

    if (! is_error_state)
        enterLoop(maxTimeout);

I think you have a misunderstanding: Topic != change number.

In principle the steps are the same as always: checkout the lastest version from Gerrit; add your changes; git commit --amend; git push refs/for/...

As long as you keep your Change-Id line in the commit message, Gerrit knows where to put that change.

done.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

Today, pressing the mouse on the grove of the slider moves the handle to that position, and changes the value. That's how sliders generally work.

So, pressing the mouse on a horizontal slider that lives in a listview would move the handle on press, and then you want to be able to scroll up or down, after the slider has changed the value? That seems very wrong to me.

We'd have to make it optional that the slider changes the value on press first.

But you probably want a different UI design; as a user I'd find it extremely confusing if a press on the slider wouldn't move the slider to that position.

subject: CMake: disable the attempt to force SIMD on iOS simulator builds

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Patch Set 1: Sanity-Review+1

Patch Set 1:

This will presumably break for a macOS univeral build where arm64 is the first arch as well?

For iOS it's okey that the simulator build is not optimized, but in the case of a macOS universal build we should enable them.

We might be able to work around it by always making x86_64 the first arch, but I don't know where in the CMake build system we'd do that.

The logic that you're modifying is dealing with SSE2 only, but if we're now grouping all x86 common intrinsics under one, can we instead add (hard-code) them all the same way?

Patch Set 1:

I don't know. I think I tried that at some point and it wasn't broken. So I don't expect this change to break what wasn't broken.

The correct change might be to provide useful defaults to the x86intrin test as well as the ARM ones in case of universal or even all Darwin builds. That way, we don't depend on the order.

I'll leave this up to you.

Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I don't know. I think I tried that at some point and it wasn't broken. So I don't expect this change to break what wasn't broken.

Ah, you are changing the logic in the followup change to set QT_FORCE_FEATURE_x86intrin, which is what I was suggesting earlier too (to not remove SS2 hard-coding, but to replace it with hard-coding of all of them).

I'd expect that approach to work for simulator as well though, so it may be that the build failure you're seeing there with missing symbols is also the case on macOS with an ARM-first universal build. I'll have to check.

> The correct change might be to provide useful defaults to the x86intrin test as well as the ARM ones in case of universal or even all Darwin builds. That way, we don't depend on the order.

Ideally we'd run the arch configure tests once per arch, or, build and run it once with two slices, and then parse the double output correctly, detecting that it's two archs.

Patch Set 2: Sanity-Review+1

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Something breaks the tst_qlowenergycontroller_device, not sure yet what. Could be that just the testcase needs updating. 

Similar result for all the test functions:

QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth: QLowEnergyControllerPrivate setting state to QLowEnergyController::DiscoveredState
QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.windows: QLowEnergyControllerPrivateWinRT::discoverServiceDetails "{4a92cb7f-5031-4a09-8304-3e89413f458d}"
QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.winrt.service.thread: QLowEnergyControllerPrivateWinRT::discoverServiceDetails Changing service pointer from thread QThread(0x2c528872bc0)
QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.windows: "Obtaining list of included services failed: 0"
FAIL!  : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() Compared values are not the same
   Actual   (((service->state())))                                    : RemoteService
   Expected (QLowEnergyService::ServiceState::RemoteServiceDiscovered): RemoteServiceDiscovered
Uploaded patch set 3.
Patch Set 3: Sanity-Review+1

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> Something breaks the tst_qlowenergycontroller_device, not sure yet what. Could be that just the testcase needs updating. 
> 
> Similar result for all the test functions:
> 
> QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth: QLowEnergyControllerPrivate setting state to QLowEnergyController::DiscoveredState
> QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.windows: QLowEnergyControllerPrivateWinRT::discoverServiceDetails "{4a92cb7f-5031-4a09-8304-3e89413f458d}"
> QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.winrt.service.thread: QLowEnergyControllerPrivateWinRT::discoverServiceDetails Changing service pointer from thread QThread(0x2c528872bc0)
> QDEBUG : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() qt.bluetooth.windows: "Obtaining list of included services failed: 0"
> FAIL!  : tst_qlowenergycontroller_device::readServerPlatform() Compared values are not the same
>    Actual   (((service->state())))                                    : RemoteService
>    Expected (QLowEnergyService::ServiceState::RemoteServiceDiscovered): RemoteServiceDiscovered

Some more details here. The problem is that after getting the service COM-pointer, the async operations on this object fail with the AccessDenied status.

We had a discussion with @Juha, and initially we thought that the problem is that the QWinRTFunctions::await() calls are yielding the thread, so we are not processing some internal Windows events in time. That also explains why we do not see any problems with lowenergyscanner example - it has delays for user interactions, so all events are processed.

I updated the patch to use the non-yielding version of await(), and the readServerPlatform() test now passes, but we have similar problem with other tests.

So simply enabling QCoreApplication::processEvents() improves the situation, but not completely. We need a more stable solution, but for that we need a better understanding of how Windows async calls work.
@Oliver, we need your help here.

P.S.: The problem that we are facing here is very similar to what's described in https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-78488, so a general solution can help with fixing that issue as well.

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Patch Set 1: Sanity-Review+1
Removed reviewer Liang Qi.

Patch Set 1:

use int64_t, and adjust the numbers in qpaintengine_raster.cpp that is supposed to avoid this case.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> use int64_t, and adjust the numbers in qpaintengine_raster.cpp that is supposed to avoid this case.

qpaintengine_raster.cpp:2375-2384 is supposed to catch the cases we can't handle due to using int.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> use int64_t, and adjust the numbers in qpaintengine_raster.cpp that is supposed to avoid this case.

Hm, the rest of that code uses qint64 & al. - any reason to mix in a third variant?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > use int64_t, and adjust the numbers in qpaintengine_raster.cpp that is supposed to avoid this case.
> 
> Hm, the rest of that code uses qint64 & al. - any reason to mix in a third variant?

Just use a 64 bit signed integer :)

long is no good, as is 32 bit on some platforms.
Uploaded patch set 2.
Patch Set 2: Sanity-Review+1

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > use int64_t, and adjust the numbers in qpaintengine_raster.cpp that is supposed to avoid this case.
> 
> Hm, the rest of that code uses qint64 & al. - any reason to mix in a third variant?

No :) 

Note there are two other possible fixes: 

1. Fix the conditions that made us take this branch. From the description is sounds like one of the dimensions is 42000 and should exceed 0x7fff, so something went wrong if we even got to this code.
2. Remove this fast branch path (qTransform struct) entirely. We already have a second fast path for non-antialiased painting in qdrawhelper, and that one is also often SIMD optimized, though while  handling a bit more cases (more work). So it might be faster or around the same speed.

(2 comments)

(2 comments)

> 
> (2 comments)

thanks for you sugession very much, up to now, i tested the crash demo,it's work fine.

Patch Set 4:

I still think you should update the limits test in qpaintengine_raster.cpp to go with this change (and figure out why it didn't trigger for this case).

Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> I still think you should update the limits test in qpaintengine_raster.cpp to go with this change (and figure out why it didn't trigger for this case).

I'm very sorry, I am not familiar with the logic of the qpaintengine_raster.cpp file, would you mind continue to modify it? thank you very much.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I've had a look at the limits test in qpaintengine_raster.cpp, and it is not at all trivial to see how it should be changed to avoid this. In fact it looks to me like there are a number of issues with that test logic, so I have created a separate jira task for it: QTBUG-99297.
In the meantime, this patch at least helps some cases.

Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)

I'm still not 100% convinced about the nature of the bug; user starts typing some characters that happen to match an entry, but doesn't press enter. Does this alone constitute an intent to change the current item?

Perhaps we should only change the current item if the user then tries to navigate up or down, so that the current item is updated before we go up and down? That wouldn't change existing programs at least, while still fixing the user experience.
Uploaded patch set 8.

Patch Set 8: Sanity-Review+1

(1 comment)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

As a user, automatic completion is telling me to select this item, which is also the reason why I modify it. If there are many items, I will be very angry if I use the direction key to switch back to the first one.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> As a user, automatic completion is telling me to select this item, which is also the reason why I modify it. If there are many items, I will be very angry if I use the direction key to switch back to the first one.

I agree, the UX bug is real; the question is whether we should update the current index as a response to typing, or only when the user presses up/down after typing. The former is a change of API behavior. Take a combobox with items


aaaa
abbb
abcc
abcd
bcde

so far, typing "a" does not emit currentChanged, neither does typing "abc". The bug is that typing "abc" + Key_Down gets you to the second entry. We want to fix that. But with your change, you get three currentChanged signal emissions from the gradual matching of "abc" (for "aaaa", for "abbb", and for "abcc", none of which was ever intended to become current). Is this what we want, or can we find a change that, when typing "abc" + Key_down, only changes the current index and emits the currentChanged signal for index 4 when you press the KeyDown, without the intermediate index updates and emissions?

For that to work, the logic would need to be part of Key_Up/Down handling - if the combobox is editable and we have a matching string, update the index from which we move just before we move, without emitting the signal.

Patch Set 14:

>

> > > > Now you’re back to emitting the currentChanged signal for partial matches when typing.
> > > > 
> > > > I think you need to make that logic happen just before you process MoveUp/Down commands, and prevent the signal emission.
> > > > 
> > > > And please use QSignalSpy to verify the signal emissions, as commented earlier.
> > > 
> > > I don't understand what you mean. Can you describe it in detail.
> > 
> > Do you mean test files or source files？

Your test needs to verify that the currentChanged signal is not emitted when the user types text that happens to (partially) match some item in the list. QSignalSpy is the tool class we have to easily count number of signal emissions, it's used in other test functions in tst_QComboBox.

I think what we want is

- current index is 0 ('aaa' item)
- user types b: current index doesn't change, no change signal
- user presses down-key: current index changes to 2 ('ccc' item), signal fires exactly once for 2

or

- current index is 0 ('aaa' item)
- user types 'b': no change signal
- user presses enter: current index changes and is activated (change and activated signals fire exactly once)

Start with writing a test that verifies that outcome.
